Vibe Specs

Have you ever fallen into the "vibe trap" of AI programming?

You sit in front of your IDE with what you think is a clear task. You confidently open the AI assistant and give a vague instruction, engaging in so-called "Vibe Coding". As a result, the AI, like an overly enthusiastic intern, gives you a bunch of seemingly reasonable but completely useless "slop software", leaving you in endless revisions and frustration.
Core Solution: Embrace "Spec-First"
LLM
Spec
Code
Vibe Specs completely overturns the traditional AI programming process. It transforms the direct path from Prompt to Code into a more stable and efficient three-step process.

The first interaction with the AI assistant is not to have it write code, but to have it help you write a requirements specification (Spec).

Seven Major Advantages

From "Conversation Drift" to "Stable Documentation"
AI conversation context easily becomes chaotic. A .md format Spec document is stable and a reliable source of truth.
From "Solo Performance" to "Team Collaboration"
AI chat history is private. A Spec document can be easily handed to colleagues or picked up again a week later with clear context.
From "No Structure" to "Version Control"
Git cannot track conversation history. But it can perfectly track the evolution of a WidgetFeature.md file.
From "Feature Creep" to "Defined Scope"
A vague request may be interpreted infinitely by AI. A clear Spec completely prevents feature creep.
From "Context Loss" to "Instant Recovery"
Project shelved for a week, forgot why you designed it this way? With Spec, you can instantly recover full context.
From "Blank Page Syndrome" to "Structured Start"
Facing a new feature and don't know where to start? Now, AI becomes your documentation assistant, helping you propose structure while you just criticize and fill in.
From "Token Waste" to "Efficient Utilization"
Rather than wasting tokens on aimless conversations, use them to generate and parse structured Specs for more precise responses.
Regardless of how AI's form evolves, from "copilot" assisting in coding to autonomous "agents", the first principle of software engineering - "define the problem clearly before solving it" - still applies. "Spec-first" is not outdated; rather, it plays the key role of "safety belt" and "navigation map" in more advanced human-machine collaboration.
